name: Antietam National Battlefield
description: 23,000 soldiers were killed, wounded or missing after twelve hours of savage combat on September 17, 1862. The Battle of Antietam ended the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia's first invasion into the North and led Abraham Lincoln to issue the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation.
shortDescription: 23,000 soldiers were killed, wounded or missing after twelve hours of savage combat on September 17, 1862. The Battle of Antietam ended the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia's first invasion into ...

operatingHours.description: The visitor center is open every day except Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Day.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: Individual: $10.00 for three days. This fee admits one individual in a vehicle and also includes hikers, bicyclists or pedestrians. Youth 15 and under are admitted free of charge.

fees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle
fees.description: Valid for 3 days. Admits up to 2 private, non-commercial motorcycles with up to 4 total passengers.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach
fees.description: $100 Motor Coach/Commercial Tour Groups with 26 or more people

fees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups
fees.description: To request an Academic Fee Waiver for your group, click on the link for further details.

climate.weatherDescription: The weather is fairly mild. Summers can be very warm and humid and winters cold and snowy. We have four distinct seasons with the fall and spring being the best times to visit the battlefield.

images.title: Memorial Illumination
images.altText: luminaries placed by Maryland Monument with dramatic orange red clouds
images.caption: The Memorial Illumination, held in December, features 23,000 candles placed by volunteers, over the north end of the battlefield.  Each represents a causality from the battle.

images.title: Antietam National Cemetery Lodge Building
images.altText: stone building with black fence in foreground
images.caption: The National Cemetery Lodge Building sits just inside the gates of the cemetery.

images.title: The Cornfield
images.altText: wood fence rails with green corn stalks behind fence
images.caption: Looking east along the south edge of The Cornfield.

images.title: Antietam Cannons
images.altText: A line Civil War cannons and a stone wall at Antietam National Battlefield
images.caption: Placing more than 500 cannons on high ground, both armies were able to effectively strike enemy troop positions at great distances.

images.title: Burnside Bridge
images.altText: three arch stone bridge over Antietam Creek
images.caption: Burnside Bridge in the snow from the Union side of Antietam Creek.

images.title: Dunker Church
images.altText: small white building with cannon in the foreground
images.caption: Spring at the Battlefield.

images.title: Dunker Church
images.altText: one room house covered in snow
images.caption: The Dunker Church covered in snow.

images.title: Monument at Sunset
images.altText: a monument of a soldier at sunset
images.caption: 130th Pennsylvania Monument at Bloody Lane

images.title: Cannon the Field
images.altText: artillery piece sitting on a rock break
images.caption: Artillery played a key role at Antietam.  Over 500 cannon were involved in the fighting.

images.title: Fog Over the Battlefield
images.altText: fog filling in the low areas of the field at sunset
images.caption: View from the visitor center looking toward Bloody Lane at sunset
